nodes.body:
Number is never marked in verbs, adjectives, or the majority of nouns. Plurality is usually implied either by context, or by quantifiers such as མང་པོ་ “many”; ཚང་མ་ “all”; ག་ཤས་ “some,” “certain”; གཉིས་ “two,” etc.

However, there is a plural marker ཚོ་, which appears with demonstratives and personal pronouns:

  • འདི་ཚོ་ “These”
  • དེ་ཚོ་ “Those”
  • ཕ་ཚོ་ “Those,” “those over there”
  • ཁོང་ཚོ་ “They,” etc.

The marker ཚོ་ by itself is used with nouns denoting people only when the people in question are specified/defined:

  • ཨ་མ་ཚོ་ “The mothers”
  • དགེ་རྒན་ཚོ་ “The teachers”
  • སློབ་གྲྭ་བ་ཚོ་ “The students”

The non-specific plural is not marked with the plural particle:

  • ཨ་མ་ “Mothers”
  • དགེ་རྒན་ “Teachers”

Furthermore, this suffix is not used with animals or inanimate objects:

  • *ལུག་ཚོ་ “[The] sheep”
  • *ཅོག་ཙེ་ཚོ་ “[The] tables”
  • *ཐང་ཀ་ཚོ་ “[The] tangkas”

Consequently, unambiguous renderings of the plural or indications of plurality require the use of demonstratives:

  • ལུག་དེ་ཚོ་ “Those sheep”
  • ཅོག་ཙེ་དེ་ཚོ་ “Those tables”

Number is only marked once per noun or noun phrase; the marker, which is placed at the end of the group, is therefore never redundant.

  • བུ་མོ་ཆུང་ཆུང་དེ་ཚོ་ “Those little girls”
  • གངས་རི་མཐོ་པོ་དེ་ཚོ་ “Those high snow-mountains”
  • ཨ་མ་གཞོན་པ་ཚོ་ “The young mothers”
  • རོགས་པ་གཞན་པ་ཚོ་ “The other companions”

Note: The following demonstratives also occur in conversation:

  • འདི་གྱད་ “These” (nearby)
  • དེ་གྱད་ “Those” (distant)
  • འདི་གྱད་འདི་ “All these”
  • དེ་གྱག་དེ་ “All those”

These last two expressions are used to make a selection from a group.

  • དེབ་འདི་གྱད་འདི་ “All these books” (and not the others)
